title: White South Africans given ‘refugee’ status arrive in US as Trump administration told they got ‘wrong end of the stick’ – live
snippets:
Trump administration welcomes 59 white South Africans as claim they faced discrimination has been widely criticized

  • Group of white South Africans arrive in US after Trump grants refugee status

Qatar has offered to donate a plane to the United States and details are still being worked out, White House spokeswoman Karoline Leavitt said on Monday.

“The Qatari Government has graciously offered to donate a plane to the Department of Defense. The legal details of that are still being worked out,” Leavitt said in an interview with Fox News.

Continue reading...
titles: White South Africans given ‘refugee’ status arrive in US as Trump administration told they got ‘wrong end of the stick’ – live

title: Coinbase Global Stock Rises. The Company Is Set to Join the S&P 500
snippets:
Shares of Coinbase Global (COIN) jumped in after-hours trading Monday on the news that the crypto exchange would be added to the S&P 500. 

The stock, which had risen roughly 4% during an upbeat regular session driven by trade-related optimism, was recently up more than 9% in late action, indicating a move toward share prices last seen in January. Bitcoin, the leading cryptocurrency, recently changed hands around $102,980. 

"Thank you to everyone who made it possible for a crypto company to join the S&P 500 for the first time in history," Coinbase said in a message on the social network X.

Coinbase will replace Discover Financial Services (DFS) in the benchmark index before trading opens next Monday, according to S&P Dow Jones Indices. Discover is set to merge with Capital One Financial (COF) after their deal got the regulatory go-ahead in April. 

Shares of Coinbase are down about 17% in 2025 through Monday’s close. The company has a market cap of roughly $50.8 billion, according to Visible Alpha data. 

Thank you to everyone who made it possible for a crypto company to join the S&P 500 for the first time in history.

— Coinbase 🛡️ (@coinbase) May 12, 2025
titles: Coinbase Global Stock Rises. The Company Is Set to Join the S&P 500
summary: Coinbase Global is set to join the S&P 500, marking the first time a cryptocurrency company has been added to the index. This news prompted a surge in Coinbase shares, which increased over 9% in after-hours trading. The inclusion in the S&P 500 follows an upbeat trading session and comes as Discover Financial Services exits the index to merge with Capital One Financial, a move already approved by regulators. Despite this milestone, Coinbase's shares are down about 17% for the year 2025, with a market capitalization of approximately $50.8 billion.
constructiveness_reason: This story informs readers about a significant development in the financial world, the inclusion of a cryptocurrency company in the S&P 500. It provides useful context about the company's stock performance and the wider implications of this inclusion. However, it does not highlight any specific solutions or improvements.

title: Why Do Some Ancient Creatures Leave Fossils While Others Disappear?
snippets: Fossilization favors larger, protein-rich animals because they create oxygen-poor conditions that slow decay, helping explain gaps in the fossil record and the dominance of arthropods in ancient deposits. Have you ever wondered why we find fossils of some ancient creatures, but others seem to disappear without a trace? A fascinating new study from the University [...]
titles: Why Do Some Ancient Creatures Leave Fossils While Others Disappear?
summary: A recent study explains why fossils of some ancient creatures are found while others are not. It reveals that fossilization is more likely to occur in larger, protein-rich animals. These animals create oxygen-poor conditions that slow down decay, which helps in their preservation. This finding sheds light on the gaps in the fossil record and why arthropods are predominantly found in ancient deposits.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it provides readers with a deeper understanding of the process of fossilization and the factors that influence it. It also increases awareness about the reasons behind the gaps in the fossil record, which is crucial for understanding the history of life on Earth.

title: Harvard Scientists Solve 100-Year Mystery of Bizarre 508-Million-Year-Old Arthropod
snippets: Helmetia expansa was found to have walking legs and molting behavior, changing assumptions about its mobility and growth. For more than a century, the Cambrian arthropod Helmetia expansa remained a mystery. Discovered in 1918 by paleontologist Charles Doolittle Walcott, it was initially identified as a crustacean. Although frequently mentioned in scientific literature, the species had [...]
titles: Harvard Scientists Solve 100-Year Mystery of Bizarre 508-Million-Year-Old Arthropod
summary: Harvard scientists have resolved a century-old enigma surrounding Helmetia expansa, a 508-million-year-old arthropod, by discovering it had walking legs and exhibited molting behavior. This finding overturns previous beliefs about its mobility and growth. Initially discovered in 1918 and mistakenly classified as a crustacean, this research offers new insights into the species' biology and evolution, marking a significant advancement in the understanding of Cambrian period arthropods.
constructiveness_reason: This news piece is constructive because it reports on a significant scientific breakthrough, providing readers with insights into the biology and evolution of an ancient arthropod species. This discovery contributes to the progress in our understanding of the Cambrian period, a key era in Earth's history.

title: Flamingos create water tornados to trap their prey
snippets: Flamingos have developed an amazing variety of techniques to create swirls and eddies in the water to concentrate and eat brine shrimp and other organisms, a biologist found. They stomp dance to stir organisms from the bottom and concentrate them in whorls. The organisms are then drawn upward by a head jerk that forms a vortex. Meanwhile, their beak is chattering underwater to create vortices that funnel prey into their mouths.
Flamingos standing serenely in a shallow alkaline lake with heads submerged may seem to be placidly feeding, but there's a lot going on under the surface.
titles: Flamingos create water tornados to trap their prey
Flamingos create water tornados to trap their prey
summary: Flamingos use sophisticated methods to feed on brine shrimp and other organisms, a biologist discovered. They perform a stomp dance to stir up organisms from the bottom, then create whirls to concentrate them. A head jerk draws the organisms upward in a vortex, while their beaks chatter underwater to create vortices that funnel prey into their mouths. This detailed feeding technique reveals a complex behavior beneath the serene appearance of flamingos feeding in shallow alkaline lakes.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful insights into the behavior of flamingos, contributing to the reader's understanding of animal behavior. It doesn't necessarily highlight a solution or progress, but it increases awareness about the complexity of nature and animal behavior.
